title: CASA and KYC
introduction: This module covers Current Account Savings Account (CASA) products and Know Your Customer (KYC) procedures. It combines detailed explanations of CASA from regulatory and practical perspectives with an overview of current account features and benefits.

content.value: CASA represents the combination of current accounts and savings accounts. These are typically low-cost deposits for banks compared to term deposits, providing a stable funding source and enabling cross-selling opportunities.

items: Lower cost of funds
Stable source of liquidity
Opportunities for additional banking services
Better profitability due to lower interest expenses

content.value: A current account is designed for businesses and individuals who need to conduct frequent and unlimited transactions. Unlike savings accounts, current accounts do not earn interest but offer high transaction limits and overdraft facilities.

items: Facilitates frequent transactions for business operations
Helps in segregating personal and business finances
Supports large cash transactions and bill payments
Unlimited transactions
Overdraft facility
Online banking capabilities through NEFT, RTGS, UPI, and IMPS
Minimum balance requirements (varies by bank)
Q: What is a current account mainly used for? A: Business transactions.
Q: Why doesnâ€™t a current account earn interest? A: Because it is designed for frequent transactions.

content.value: KYC (Know Your Customer) procedures are regulatory requirements to verify the identity of customers, preventing fraud and money laundering. This involves document collection, verification, risk assessment, and periodic updates.

items: Customer Identification using valid documents
Customer Due Diligence (CDD) to assess risk
Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD) for high-risk profiles
Ongoing monitoring of account activities
Identity Proof (PAN, Passport, Aadhaar, etc.)
Address Proof (Utility bills, Rental agreement, etc.)
Recent passport-sized photograph
